original: Brilioth, Yngve Torgny, biskop, Växjö, f. 12/7/91 i V. Ed, Kalmar 1., av kyrkoh. Herm. B. o. Gertrud Eke-man. G. 19 m. Brita Söderblom. Barn: Ingrid f. 20, fil. mag., g. m. fil. mag. Claes Schaar, Margareta 22, g. 42 m. hovr :fiiskalen, greve Carl Hamilton, Cecilia 24, fil. kand., g. m. pol. mag. Sven Moberg, Lars-Olof 26, Helge 31, Erik Gustaf 41. — Fil. lic. 13, fil. dr 16, teol. kand. 17, prästv. 18. Stud:reisa is; Thunsk. stip. huv:-sakl. t. Engl. 19-20. Past:adj. i Upps. 19, doc. i kyrkohist. v. Upps. univ. 19, prof. i kyrkohist. v. Abo akad. 25, prof. i prakt. teol. o. domprost i Lund 28, biskop i Växjö stift sed. 37. Ordf. i 34 års domkap :’sakk., i 44 års präst-utb:sakk. o. i styr. f. Växjö hantv:sk. f. blinda kvinnor, insp. f. småsk:sem. i Växjö, led. of the Provisional Com-mittee of the World Council of Chur-ches. Teol. hed:dr i Åbo 24, i Upps. 27, i Oxford 33, i Glasgow 35, hed:led. av Östg. o. Smål. nat. i Upps. o. Lund o. av Kalmar nat. i Upps. Skr.: Den påvl. beskattn. av Sverige (16), Nyang- lik, renässans I-III (i Kyrko’hist. Ärs-skr. 21-23, eng. uppl.: The Anglican Revival 25), Tidernas konung (24), Sv. kyrka, kungadöme o. påvemakt 1363-1414 (25), Nattvarden i evang. gudstjänstliv (26), eng. bearb.: Eucharistic faith and practice (30), Den Eviges ansikte (29), Sv. kyrkokunskap (33), Evangelicalism and The Oxford Mo-vement (34), Kyrkokristendom (35), Kampen om kyrkan (37), Herdabrev (38), I S:t Sigfrids stift (40), Sv. kyrkans hist., II: Den sen. medelt. 1274-1521 (41), Kristen folkuppfostran förr o. nu (42), Betänk, m. för si. rör. ändr. av gäll. best. i fråga om prästutb. (42), Det levande ordet (43), Predikans historia (45), fl. upps. i Kyrkohist. Års-skr. o. kyrkl. tidskr. o. publ. KNOlkl, RDDO, tilld. av ärkebisk. av Canterbury hed:t. Lambeth Cross 42, tilld. av Sv. akad. det kungl. priset f. kyrkohist. författarskap 44, LLHS, LVSL.
translated: Brilioth, Yngve Torgny, bishop of Växjö, born on July 12, 1891 in V. Ed, Kalmar county, son of the clergyman Herm. B. and Gertrud Eke-man. Married in 1919 to Brita Söderblom. Children: Ingrid, born in 1920 and graduated with a Master of Arts, married to Claes Schaar who also has a Master of Arts degree, Margareta, born in 1922, married in 1942 to Court of Appeal judge, Count Carl Hamilton, Cecilia, born in 1924 with a Bachelor of Arts degree, married to political scientist Sven Moberg, Lars-Olof, born in 1926, Helge, born in 1931, Erik Gustaf, born in 1941. Obtained a Licentiate degree in Literature in 1913, a PhD degree in Literature in 1916, a Bachelor of Theology in 1917, and ordained as a priest in 1918. Studied in Thun, Switzerland in 1919-1920 with a scholarship for main study in England. Was a pastorate assistant in Uppsala in 1919 and became a lecturer in church history at Uppsala University the same year. He was appointed as a professor of church history at Abo Academy in 1925, professor of Practical Theology and Dean of Lund Cathedral in 1928, and appointed as bishop of Växjö in 1937. He chaired the Ecclesiastical Board of the Year 1934, the Priest Education Committee of the Year 1944, and was a member of the Vaxjo Handicrafts for Blind Women. He was also an inspector for kindergarten teachers in Växjö, and led the Provisional Committee of the World Council of Churches. He received an honorary doctorate in Theology in Åbo in 1924, in Uppsala in 1927, in Oxford in 1933, and in Glasgow in 1935. He was an honorary member of the Eastern and Smaland Nationalities in Uppsala and Lund, and in Kalmar Nationalities in Uppsala. He authored several books including "The Taxation of Sweden by the Pope" in 1916, "The Anglican Revival" in 1925, "Eucharistic Faith and Practice" in 1930, "The Face of the Eternal" in 1929, "Swedish Church Knowledge" in 1933, "Evangelicalism and the Oxford Movement" in 1934, "Church Christianity" in 1935, "The Struggle for the Church" in 1937, "Pastoral Letters" in 1938, "In St. Sigfrid's Diocese" in 1940, "History of the Swedish Church, Vol. II: The Late Middle Ages 1274-1521" in 1941, "Christian Folk Education Past and Present" in 1942, "Proposals for Amending Existing Regulations on Priest Education" in 1942, "The Living Word" in 1943 and "The History of Sermons" in 1945. He published many other studies in Church History Yearbook and ecclesiastical journals and was awarded the Lambeth Cross honour by the Archbishop of Canterbury in 1942 and the Royal Swedish Academy's Royal Prize for Church History in 1944. He also received LLHS and LVSL distinction.
